com.idevicesinc.sweetblue

Class BleTransaction

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.idevicesinc.sweetblue.BleTransaction
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BleTransaction.Auth, BleTransaction.Init, BleTransaction.Ota

    public abstract class BleTransaction
extends Object
    Abstract base class for transactions passed to various methods of BleDevice. Transactions provide a convenient way to encapsulate a series of reads and writes for things like authentication handshakes, firmware updates, etc. You optionally provide subclass instances to the various overloads of BleDevice.connect(). Normally in your start(BleDevice) method you then do some reads/writes and call succeed() or fail() depending on the BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.Status returned.

    NOTE: Nested subclasses here are only meant for tagging to enforce type-correctness and don't yet provide any differing contracts or implementations.
    See Also:
    BleDevice.performOta(BleTransaction.Ota), BleDevice.connect(BleTransaction.Auth), BleDevice.connect(BleTransaction.Init), BleDevice.connect(BleTransaction.Auth, BleTransaction.Init), BleDevice.performTransaction(BleTransaction)

      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  BleTransaction.Auth
      Tagging subclass to force type-discrepancy for various BleDevice.connect() overloads.
      protected static class  BleTransaction.EndReason
      Values are passed to onEnd(BleDevice, EndReason).
      static class  BleTransaction.Init
      Tagging subclass to force type-discrepancy for various BleDevice.connect() overloads.
      static class  BleTransaction.Ota
      Tagging subclass to force type-correctness for BleDevice.performOta(BleTransaction.Ota).

    • Constructor Detail

      • BleTransaction

        public BleTransaction()

    • Method Detail

      • getDevice

        public BleDevice getDevice()
        Returns the device this transaction is running on.

      • start

        protected abstract void start(BleDevice device)
        Implement this method to kick off your transaction. Usually you kick off some reads/writes inside your override and call succeed() or fail() depending on how things went.

      • onEnd

        protected void onEnd(BleDevice device,
                     BleTransaction.EndReason reason)
        Called when a transaction ends, either due to the transaction itself finishing itself through fail() or succeed(), or from the library implicitly ending the transaction, for example if getDevice() becomes BleDeviceState.DISCONNECTED. Override this method to wrap up any loose ends or notify UI or what have you.

      • update

        protected void update(double timeStep)
        Optional convenience method to override if you want to do periodic updates or time-based calculations.

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Returns whether the transaction is currently running.

      • fail

        protected final boolean fail()
        Call this from subclasses to indicate that the transaction has failed. Usually you call this in your BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.onEvent(BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent) when BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.Status is something other than BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.Status.SUCCESS. If you do so, BleDevice.ConnectionFailListener.ConnectionFailEvent.txnFailReason() will be set.
        Returns:
        false if the transaction wasn't running to begin with.

      • succeed

        protected final boolean succeed()
        Call this from subclasses to indicate that the transaction has succeeded.
        Returns:
        Boolean.FALSE if the transaction wasn't running to begin with.

      • getTime

        protected double getTime()
        Returns the total time that this transaction has been running. You can use this in update(double) for example to fail() or succeed() a transaction that has taken longer than a certain amount of time.
        See Also:
        update(double)

      • needsAtomicity

        protected boolean needsAtomicity()
        Default is Boolean.FALSE. Optionally override if you want your transaction's reads/writes to execute "atomically". This means that if you're connected to multiple devices only the reads/writes of this transaction's device will be executed until this transaction is finished.
